abstracts.cdata!:
The Programmatic Education Sector
            Adjustment Credit Project, will assist the Ministry of
            Education (MOE) in undertaking the first phase of a
            medium-term reform agenda, aimed at addressing systemic
            governance issues in order to raise the quality, and
            cost-effectiveness of service delivery, and improve equity
            of access in secondary education. The focus will be on
            reforms, to include a rigorous, and enforced criteria, that
            governs the establishment of institutions, and of
            institutional mechanisms that link school subsidies, to
            objective measures of school performance. Also strengthened,
            will be the school management committees, to allow them a
            greater role in school management. To enhance access to
            secondary schooling, MOE has been proves subsidies to girls
            at the secondary level, and, over the next few years,
            means-testing mechanisms will be piloted to better target
            these subsidies to the poor. Incentives will be provided to
            the private sector to set up institutions in underserved
            areas. Moreover, significant emphasis will be placed on
            program evaluation and monitoring to guide policymaking,
            namely information on standardized examination outcomes,
            school performance, and on program effectiveness. An
            autonomous Teacher registration and certification agency
            will be established, responsible for developing a roster of
            pre-qualified, and certified teachers. An apex institution
            will also be established to manage teacher training, and
            regulate training institutions, and, set standards for new,
            and in-service teachers. Finally, an enhanced transparency
            in textbook production and relevant, demand-driven
            curriculum will focus on privatizing textbook production,
            through the National Curriculum and Textbook Board (NCTB).
